messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] sayagaki/tsunagi
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Darcy: I think you have to consider the possibility that more than one of the blades in the auction had papers and more, and that they either got misplaced
messages.messageBody:
Hi Darcy:
I think you have to consider the possibility that more than one of the
blades in the auction had papers and more, and that they either got
misplaced during the shuffle or perhaps were of such stature that
leaving Japan might have been a problem in that exports are being
checked more carefully now.
Regards, Arnold

>>> samurai@... 01/14/05 6:39 PM >>>

<afrenzel@...> writes:

> Wouldn't it just be a reminder that there is an origami? Arnold

That's what I thought, then when I saw the tsunagi I thought that was a
very strange thing to be writing on the tsunagi.

Whenever I've seen it on a tsunagi before, it's always something like
the long name of the smith, or else the signature that is on the blade.

- darcy





Yahoo! Groups Links

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] sayagaki/tsunagi
messages.msgSnippet: How about; The blade with a Senjuin Origami Subtext: your opinion may vary. At least once at the Kamakura kantei-kai we were presented with a blade which
messages.messageBody:
How about;
"The blade with a Senjuin Origami" Subtext: your opinion may vary.

At least once at the Kamakura kantei-kai we were presented with a blade
which carried an origami by Hon'Ami Koson, but had since been reevaluated
by
the Kyokai. Sorry I can't remember the smiths off-hand but we were rewarded
with points for pegging the Kyokais attribution or Koson's though they were
different artists. Since the majority of bids were for the smith assigned
by
Koson, the comment was made that at least in this case his attribution was
spot on, but of course the home office is never wrong. Therefore we had to
choose for ourselves which we thought was correct...
-t

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] sayagaki/tsunagi
messages.msgSnippet: Still, the shira-saya is with the blade and the tsunagi is with the mounts, so the information that the blade has an origami is provided in two distinct areas.
messages.messageBody:
Still, the shira-saya is with the blade and the tsunagi is with the
mounts, so the information that the blade has an origami is provided in
two distinct areas. Or, that is what it seems to me.

Gordon

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba theme ?
messages.msgSnippet: Richard, It looks like a peony flower bud. http://www.mnwelldir.org/docs/fruits/images/peony_bud.jpg
messages.messageBody:
Richard,
It looks like a peony flower bud.
http://www.mnwelldir.org/docs/fruits/images/peony_bud.jpg
http://www.oznet.ksu.edu/dp_hfrr/HortImage/Paenonia%20lactiflora%20in%20bud.jpg
http://www.paeonia.ch/bildber/b0651gp01.jpg

But there are plenty of Japanese plants I haven't seen in bud.

Jim




All, on this tsuba, I have determined that there are 2 geese ( wild or
otherwise ) 2 ginger leaves but the flower, it reminds me of a thistle
of some kind, would it be part of the ginger plant or a third item ?.

cheers

Richard Turner

http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/tsuba_collection/ko-akasaka-geese.jpg

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] sayagaki/tsunagi
messages.msgSnippet: Darcy et al- If we want to speculate I would say it is a name. The Senjuin with Origami to distinguish it from say the signed Senjuin pieces and or the
messages.messageBody:
Darcy et al-
If we want to speculate I would say it is a name. "The Senjuin with
Origami" to distinguish it from say the signed Senjuin pieces and or the
unsigned ones that entered the museums collection without a (Hon'Ami)
Origami...

-t

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] sayagaki/tsunagi
messages.msgSnippet: Yes, origami. Gordon ... From: samurai@xhasc.com [mailto:samurai@xhasc.com] Sent: Wednesday, January 12, 2005 2:21 PM To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com Subject:
messages.messageBody:
Yes, origami.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: samurai@... [mailto:samurai@...]
Sent: Wednesday, January 12, 2005 2:21 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] sayagaki/tsunagi




Hi all... on the Senjuin from the fittings museum, there is a short
sayagaki which is mirrored on the tsunagi for the fittings.

Here's a picture:

http://www.nihonto.ca/senjuin/koshirae/ss/2.jpg

The last three characters read Senjuin pretty clearly.

The first two I read as "Origami???"

I'm not 100% confident because it's not making sense to me, unless it's
intended as a name? I dunno. Can anyone verify my translation and/or
provide a guess as to the meaning?

Thanks,

- darcy
